**Crime and Punishment**  
**Translatorâ€™s Preface**

A few words about Dostoevsky himself may help the English reader to understand his work.

Dostoevsky was the son of a doctor. His parents were very hard-working and deeply religious, but they were so poor that they lived with their five children in just two rooms. The father and mother spent their evenings reading aloud to their children, usually from serious books.

Even though he was often sick and weak, Dostoevsky finished third in his final exam at the Petersburg school of Engineering. There, he started his first work, "Poor Folk." This story was published by the poet Nekrassov in his magazine and was very well received. The shy, unknown young man suddenly became somewhat famous. A bright and successful future seemed to be ahead of him, but those hopes were quickly crushed. In 1849, he was arrested.

Although he was not a revolutionary by nature or belief, Dostoevsky was part of a small group of young men who met to read the works of Fourier and Proudhon. **PAGE SUMMARY:** Dostoevsky, despite his promising beginnings as a writer, faced arrest in 1849 for his involvement in discussions against censorship.
